Quick Naan

Jump to Recipe

Welcome to our delightful journey of making Quick Naan, a beloved Indian flatbread that's perfect for scooping up your favorite dishes or enjoying on its own! This easy naan recipe is not only quick to prepare but also requires minimal ingredients, making it a great option for both beginners and seasoned cooks alike. With just a handful of pantry staples like all-purpose flour, yogurt, and baking powder, you can create soft, fluffy naan bread in no time. Whether you're serving it with rich curries, savory stews, or enjoying it as a snack with some garlic butter, this naan is sure to elevate your meal experience. Get ready to impress your family and friends with this homemade goodness that tastes just like it came from your favorite Indian restaurant!

Ingredients

all-purpose flour

All-purpose flour is versatile and works well for naan, but you can also use bread flour for a chewier texture. If you need a gluten-free option, substitute with a gluten-free flour blend, but add a binding agent like xanthan gum.

yogurt

Yogurt adds moisture and tang to the naan. You can substitute with Greek yogurt for a thicker consistency or non-dairy yogurt (like coconut or almond) for a dairy-free version. If using non-dairy yogurt, check for added sugars as they can affect the dough.

baking powder

Baking powder helps the naan rise quickly. If you don't have baking powder, you can substitute with baking soda (use half the amount) and add an acid like vinegar or lemon juice to activate it.

salt

Salt enhances flavor, but if you're on a low-sodium diet, you can reduce the amount or use a salt substitute. A pinch of garlic or onion powder can also add a savory note if you want to experiment.

water

Water is used to adjust the dough consistency. Use warm water to help activate the yogurt and achieve a softer dough. If you're looking to infuse flavor, consider using milk instead of water.

olive oil or melted butter

Brushing the naan with olive oil or melted butter adds richness. You can also use ghee for a traditional flavor. For a herb-infused option, mix minced garlic or chopped herbs (like cilantro or parsley) with the oil or butter before brushing.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Combine Dry Ingredients

    In a mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of all-purpose flour, 1 teaspoon of baking powder, and 1/2 teaspoon of salt. This mixture forms the base of your naan. Make sure to sift the flour to ensure there are no lumps, which will help in achieving a light and fluffy texture.

  • Step 2: Add Yogurt

    Add 1/2 cup of yogurt to the dry mixture. Yogurt adds moisture and helps to create a soft, pliable dough. If you’re using a thick yogurt, you may need to add a bit more water.

  • Step 3: Form the Dough

    Gradually add 1/4 cup of water, a little at a time, while mixing the ingredients with your hands. Continue until you form a soft dough. The dough should not be sticky; adjust the water or flour as needed.

  • Step 4: Knead the Dough

    Knead the dough for about 2 minutes on a lightly floured surface. The goal is to make it smooth and elastic. Once kneaded, cover the dough with a clean kitchen towel or plastic wrap and let it rest for 5 minutes. This resting period allows the gluten to relax, which makes rolling easier.

  • Step 5: Divide the Dough

    After resting, divide the dough into 4 equal pieces. Roll each piece into a ball. This helps ensure that all your naan will be the same size and cook evenly.

  • Step 6: Roll Out the Naan

    On a floured surface, take one ball and roll it out into an oval shape, about 1/4 inch thick. Don’t worry about making it perfectly oval; a rustic shape adds to the charm of homemade naan.

  • Step 7: Cook the Naan

    Heat a non-stick skillet over medium-high heat. Once hot, place the rolled naan on the skillet. Cook for about 2-3 minutes on each side or until golden brown spots appear. If your naan puffs up, that’s a good sign! It means your dough is working well.

  • Step 8: Brush with Olive Oil or Butter

    Once cooked, remove the naan from the skillet and brush it with 2 tablespoons of olive oil or melted butter. This not only adds flavor but also keeps the naan soft.

Frequently Asked Questions

What is the best way to measure flour accurately?

To measure flour accurately, use the spoon and level method. Spoon the flour into a measuring cup without packing it down, then level it off with a straight edge, like a knife. This prevents you from adding too much flour, which can make your naan dense.

Can I substitute Greek yogurt for regular yogurt in naan?

Yes, you can substitute Greek yogurt for regular yogurt. It might make the naan a bit thicker and richer, but it will still work well in the recipe.

What should I do if my dough is too sticky?

If your dough is too sticky, sprinkle a little more flour on your work surface and knead it in until the dough becomes manageable. Be careful not to add too much flour at once.

How do I know when the naan is cooked through?

Naan is cooked when it has golden brown spots on both sides and puffs up slightly. You can also press it gently; if it feels springy and holds its shape, it’s ready.

Is it okay to use a regular skillet instead of a non-stick one?

Yes, you can use a regular skillet, but make sure it's well-seasoned to prevent sticking. You may need to adjust the heat to prevent burning.

How can I store leftover naan?

Store leftover naan in an airtight container at room temperature for up to a day. For longer storage, wrap it tightly in plastic wrap and freeze it. To reheat, simply warm it in a skillet or microwave.

What can I serve with naan?

Naan pairs well with various dishes, such as curries, stews, or even as a base for pizzas. You can also serve it with dips like hummus or tzatziki.

How do I know when to flip the naan in the skillet?

Look for bubbles forming on the surface of the naan. When you see these bubbles and the bottom is golden brown, it’s time to flip it.

Can I add herbs or spices to the naan dough?

Absolutely! You can add herbs like chopped cilantro or spices like garlic powder or cumin to the dough for added flavor.

What's the purpose of letting the dough rest?

Letting the dough rest helps relax the gluten, making it easier to roll out and resulting in a softer texture in the finished naan.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

This Quick Naan recipe contains dairy due to the yogurt. For a dairy-free version, use a plant-based yogurt alternative. The recipe is vegetarian-friendly, and you can easily make it vegan by substituting yogurt with an appropriate vegan yogurt and using olive oil instead of butter. Since it contains gluten, it is not suitable for those with gluten intolerance; however, gluten-free all-purpose flour can be used as a substitute.

Pairings

For a delicious meal, serve Quick Naan with a variety of dishes such as Chicken Tikka Masala, Paneer Butter Masala, or a spicy lentil stew (Dal). For beverages, pair with Mango Lassi or a light, crisp Indian lager like Kingfisher. You can also enjoy it with a side of yogurt dip or a tangy chutney for added flavor.

Serving Suggestions

Serve Quick Naan warm, freshly brushed with olive oil or melted butter, stacked in a bread basket lined with a clean kitchen towel to keep them warm. Consider garnishing with fresh herbs like cilantro or sprinkle with sesame seeds for added texture and flavor. For a more elevated experience, serve alongside a platter of various dips like hummus, raita, or tzatziki to complement the naan.

#

Quick Naan

20 min
$2.5
150 kcal
Difficulty: 20%
Servings: 4

Allergens:

GlutenDairy (if using yogurt)

Dietary Tags:

VegetarianVegan option

Cuisine:

IndianMiddle Eastern

Course:

SideBread

Tags:

BreadQuickEasy

Description

Soft and fluffy naan bread made in minutes, perfect for dipping or wrapping!

Ingredients

  • all-purpose flour: 2 cups
  • yogurt: 1/2 cup
  • baking powder: 1 teaspoon
  • salt: 1/2 teaspoon
  • water: 1/4 cup (as needed)
  • olive oil or melted butter: 2 tablespoons (for brushing)
